entry.title: Gitå®˜ç½‘ä¿¡æ¯
entry.content:
Gitå®˜ç½‘ä¸Šçš„ä¿¡æ¯ï¼ˆç¬¬ä¸€æ‰‹èµ„æ–™ï¼‰

ä¸»é¡µé¢ï¼ˆå®˜ç½‘çš„ä¿¡æ¯å¯¹åˆå­¦è€…å¹¶ä¸å‹å¥½ï¼‰

  • Git is a free and open source distributed version control system designed to handle everything from small to very large projects with speed and efficiency.

    Gitæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå…è´¹ã€å¼€æºçš„åˆ†å¸ƒå¼ç‰ˆæœ¬æ§åˆ¶ç³»ç»Ÿï¼Œç”¨äºå¿«é€Ÿé«˜æ•ˆåœ°å¤„ç†å°å‹-å¤§å‹é¡¹ç›®ï¼›

    é“¾æ¥è¯¦æƒ…ï¼š

    • Gitå¼€æºéµå®ˆçš„æ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆç±»å‹çš„è®¸å¯è¯ï¼›
      • ä½œç”¨ï¼šä½ å¯ä»¥æ‹¿Gitåšå“ªäº›äº‹ï¼Œåˆä¸è‡³äºè¿åè§„åˆ™ï¼›
      • ç‰¹å¾ï¼šå¯¹ä½ æˆ‘è¿™ç§ä¸åŒçš„ç¨‹åºå‘˜ä¸é‡è¦ï¼Œåˆ«å¤šæƒ³ğŸ˜³

  • Git is easy to learn and has a tiny footprint with lightning fast performance. It outclasses SCM tools like Subversion, CVS, Perforce, and ClearCase with features like cheap local branching, convenient staging areas, and multiple workflows.

    Gitå¾ˆå®¹æ˜“å­¦ä¹ å¹¶ä¸”å ç”¨ç©ºé—´å¾ˆå°ï¼ˆtiny footprintï¼‰ï¼Œé€Ÿåº¦å¿«ã€‚

    å®ƒè¶…è¶Šäº†å¾ˆå¤šSCMï¼ˆSoftware configuration managementï¼‰å·¥å…·ï¼ˆæ¯”å¦‚Subversion, CVS, å…¶ä»–åŒç±»å“ï¼‰,å…·ä½“åŸå› åœ¨äºå¿«æ·çš„æœ¬åœ°åˆ†æ”¯ã€æ–¹ä¾¿çš„æš‚å­˜åŒºã€å¤šä¸ªå·¥ä½œæµï¼›

é“¾æ¥è¯¦æƒ…1ï¼šeasy to learn
  • 1 ä½¿ç”¨æ‰‹å†Œ/cheat sheetï¼›
  • 2 ä¹¦ï¼›
  • 3 è§†é¢‘ï¼›

æˆ‘å°±çº³é—·äº†ï¼Œè¦æ˜¯å®¹æ˜“å­¦çš„è¯ã€‚è¿˜éœ€è¦ä¸€æœ¬ä¹¦å—ï¼ŸğŸ™‹

é“¾æ¥è¯¦æƒ…2ï¼štiny footprint with lightning fast performance

Git is fast. With Git, nearly all operations are performed locally, giving it a huge speed advantage on centralized systems that constantly have to communicate with a server somewhere.

Git was built to work on the Linux kernel, meaning that it has had to effectively handle large repositories from day one. Git is written in C, reducing the overhead of runtimes associated with higher-level languages. Speed and performance has been a primary design goal of the Git from the start.

ç¿»è¯‘ï¼š

Gitå¾ˆå¿«. ä½¿ç”¨Gitæ—¶,å‡ ä¹æ‰€æœ‰çš„æ“ä½œéƒ½æ˜¯åœ¨æœ¬åœ°æ‰§è¡Œçš„â€”æ¯”èµ·é›†ä¸­å¼çš„ç³»ç»Ÿï¼Œè¿™ç»™äº†Gitä¸€ä¸ªå·¨å¤§çš„é€Ÿåº¦ä¼˜åŠ¿ï¼ˆå› ä¸ºé›†ä¸­å¼çš„ç³»ç»Ÿæ€»æ˜¯ä¼šä¸æŸä¸ªè¿œç¨‹çš„æœåŠ¡å™¨æ‰§è¡Œç½‘ç»œæ“ä½œï¼‰

Gitæ˜¯ä¸ºäº†åœ¨Linuxå†…æ ¸ä¸Šå·¥ä½œè€Œåˆ›å»ºçš„,è¿™æ„å‘³ç€å®ƒä¸€å¼€å§‹å°±å¿…é¡»èƒ½å¤Ÿæœ‰æ•ˆåœ°å¤„ç†å¤§çš„ä»“åº“;

Gitæ˜¯ç”¨Cè¯­è¨€å†™æˆçš„ï¼Œè¿™å‡å°‘äº†ä½¿ç”¨é«˜çº§è¯­è¨€æ—¶ä¼šäº§ç”Ÿçš„è¿è¡Œæ—¶å¼€é”€ï¼›

é€Ÿåº¦ä¸æ€§èƒ½æ˜¯è®¾è®¡Gitæ—¶è€ƒè™‘çš„é¦–è¦ç›®æ ‡ï¼›

Letâ€™s see how common operations stack up against Subversion, a common centralized version control system that is similar to CVS or Perforce. Smaller is faster.

ç¿»è¯‘ï¼šè®©æˆ‘ä»¬çœ‹ä¸€ä¸‹Gitåœ¨å¸¸ç”¨æ“ä½œä¸­ä¸Subversionçš„æ¯”æ‹¼ï¼ˆSubxxxæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå¸¸ç”¨çš„ä¸­å¿ƒåŒ–ç‰ˆæœ¬æ§åˆ¶ç³»ç»Ÿ,å®ƒä¸CVSæˆ–è€…Perforceè¿™äº›ä¸ªäº§å“ç±»ä¼¼ï¼‰ æ›´å°æ„å‘³ç€æ›´å¿«

çœ‹ä¸å¤ªæ‡‚çš„å›¾ç‰‡

è™½ç„¶ä¸å¤ªæ¸…æ¥šå…·ä½“æ˜¯å•¥æ„æ€ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯gitçš„æ¡çŠ¶å›¾æ˜æ˜¾ä½å¾ˆå¤šâ€¦

ä¸è¿‡æ—¢ç„¶æ˜¯åœ¨å¯¹Gitå’ŒSubversionè¿›è¡Œæ“ä½œè€—æ—¶æ¯”è¾ƒ,è‚¯å®šéœ€è¦å‡†å¤‡ç›¸åŒçš„æµ‹è¯•ç”¨ä¾‹ï¼Œç„¶åè¿›è¡ŒåŒæ ·çš„æ“ä½œï¼ˆåˆä¸­ç‰©ç†ä¹‹æ§åˆ¶å˜é‡æ³•ï¼‰

For testing, large AWS instances were set up in the same availability zone. Git and SVN were installed on both machines, the Ruby repository was copied to both Git and SVN servers, and common operations were performed on both.

æµ‹è¯•æ¡ä»¶ï¼š

1 åœ¨åŒä¸€å¯ç”¨åŒºåŸŸä¸­è®¾ç½®äº†å¤§å‹AWSå®ä¾‹ï¼›

2 Gitå’ŒSVNéƒ½å®‰è£…åœ¨è¿™ä¸¤å°æœºå™¨ä¸Šï¼›

3 Rubyå­˜å‚¨åº“è¢«å¤åˆ¶åˆ°Gitå’ŒSVNæœåŠ¡å™¨ä¸Šï¼Œå¹¶åœ¨è¿™ä¸¤å°æœºå™¨ä¸Šæ‰§è¡Œå¸¸è§æ“ä½œã€‚

In some cases the commands donâ€™t match up exactly. Here, matching on the lowest common denominator was attempted. For example, the â€˜commitâ€™ tests also include the time to push for Git, though most of the time you would not actually be pushing to the server immediately after a commit where the two commands cannot be separated in SVN.

æµ‹è¯•çš„ä¸ç²¾ç¡®æ€§è¯´æ˜ï¼š

åœ¨æŸäº›æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œå‘½ä»¤ä¸é¢„æœŸæ“ä½œå¹¶ä¸å®Œå…¨åŒ¹é…ã€‚æ‰€ä»¥åœ¨è¿™é‡Œï¼Œå°è¯•åœ¨æœ€å°å…¬åˆ†æ¯ä¸Šè¿›è¡ŒåŒ¹é…ã€‚
ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œâ€œcommitâ€æµ‹è¯•è¿˜åŒ…æ‹¬æ¨é€Gitçš„æ—¶é—´â€”â€”å¤šæ•°æƒ…å†µä¸‹æ‚¨ä¸ä¼šåœ¨æäº¤ä¹‹åç«‹å³æ¨é€åˆ°æœåŠ¡å™¨ï¼ˆä½†æ˜¯åœ¨SVNä¸­ä¸¤ä¸ªå‘½ä»¤ä¸èƒ½åˆ†å¼€ï¼‰

å®éªŒæ•°æ®(å•ä½ä¸ºs)ï¼›

  • åˆ†æ”¯ä¸åˆå¹¶

The Git feature that really makes it stand apart from nearly every other SCM out there is its branching model.

Git allows and encourages you to have multiple local branches that can be entirely independent of each other. The creation, merging, and deletion of those lines of development takes seconds.

Gitæ‰€ä»¥åŒºåˆ«äºå…¶ä»–çš„SCM(Software configuration management)å·¥å…·çš„ä¸»è¦åŸå› åœ¨äºï¼šå®ƒçš„åˆ†æ”¯æ¨¡å‹ï¼›

Gitå…è®¸/é¼“åŠ±ä½ æŒæœ‰å¤šä¸ªç›¸äº’ç‹¬ç«‹çš„æœ¬åœ°åˆ†æ”¯ï¼›

è¿™äº›ä¸ªåˆ†æ”¯ï¼ˆå¼€å‘çº¿ï¼‰çš„åˆ›å»ºã€åˆå¹¶ä¸åˆ é™¤éƒ½åªæ˜¯å‡ ç§’é’Ÿçš„å·¥ä½œï¼›

  • åˆ†æ”¯æ¨¡å‹çš„ä½œç”¨

This means that you can do things like:

  • Frictionless Context Switching.
    • Create a branch to try out an idea, commit a few times, switch back to where you branched from, apply a patch, switch back to where you are experimenting, and merge it in.
  • Role-Based Codelines. Have a branch that always contains only what goes to production, another that you merge work into for testing, and several smaller ones for day to day work.

  • Feature Based Workflow. Create new branches for each new feature youâ€™re working on so you can seamlessly switch back and forth between them, then delete each branch when that feature gets merged into your main line.

Notably, when you push to a remote repository, you do not have to push all of your branches. You can choose to share just one of your branches, a few of them, or all of them. This tends to free people to try new ideas without worrying about having to plan how and when they are going to merge it in or share it with others.

There are ways to accomplish some of this with other systems, but the work involved is much more difficult and error-prone. Git makes this process incredibly easy and it changes the way most developers work when they learn it.

Unlike the other systems, Git has something called the â€œstaging areaâ€ or â€œindexâ€. This is an intermediate area where commits can be formatted and reviewed before completing the commit.

One thing that sets Git apart from other tools is that itâ€™s possible to quickly stage some of your files and commit them without committing all of the other modified files in your working directory or having to list them on the command line during the commit.

This allows you to stage only portions of a modified file. Gone are the days of making two logically unrelated modifications to a file before you realized that you forgot to commit one of them. Now you can just stage the change you need for the current commit and stage the other change for the next commit. This feature scales up to as many different changes to your file as needed.

Distributed(åˆ†é…/åˆ†å‘)

One of the nicest features of any Distributed SCM, Git included, is that itâ€™s distributed. This means that instead of doing a â€œcheckoutâ€ of the current tip of the source code, you do a â€œcloneâ€ of the entire repository.

åˆ†å¸ƒå¼SCMå·¥å…·ï¼ˆåŒ…æ‹¬Gitï¼‰çš„æœ€å¥½çš„ä¸€ä¸ªç‰¹æ€§å°±æ˜¯ï¼šå®ƒæ˜¯distributedçš„ã€‚

Multiple Backups

This means that even if youâ€™re using a centralized workflow, every user essentially has a full backup of the main server. Each of these copies could be pushed up to replace the main server in the event of a crash or corruption. In effect, there is no single point of failure with Git unless there is only a single copy of the repository.

Subversion-Style Workflow

A centralized workflow is very common, especially from people transitioning from a centralized system. Git will not allow you to push if someone has pushed since the last time you fetched, so a centralized model where all developers push to the same server works just fine.

Integration Manager Workflow

Another common Git workflow involves an integration manager â€” a single person who commits to the â€˜blessedâ€™ repository. A number of developers then clone from that repository, push to their own independent repositories, and ask the integrator to pull in their changes. This is the type of development model often seen with open source or GitHub repositories.

Dictator and Lieutenants Workflow

For more massive projects, a development workflow like that of the Linux kernel is often effective. In this model, some people (â€˜lieutenantsâ€™) are in charge of a specific subsystem of the project and they merge in all changes related to that subsystem. Another integrator (the â€˜dictatorâ€™) can pull changes from only his/her lieutenants and then push to the â€˜blessedâ€™ repository that everyone then clones from again.
